member.name: T:FluentTransitions.InterpolationMethod
member.summary: Interpolation methods to

member.name: F:FluentTransitions.InterpolationMethod.Linear
member.summary: Alters values in a linear way until they reach their destination values.

member.name: F:FluentTransitions.InterpolationMethod.Accleration
member.summary: Alters values to their destination values from a standing start with accelerating intervals.

member.name: F:FluentTransitions.InterpolationMethod.Deceleration
member.summary: Alters values starting from a high speed and decelerating to zero by the end of the transition.

member.name: F:FluentTransitions.InterpolationMethod.EaseInEaseOut
member.summary: Alters values in an ease-in-ease-out transition. This accelerates during the first half of the transition, and then decelerates during the second half.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.IManagedType
member.summary: Interface for all types we can perform transitions on. Each type (e.g. int, double, Color) that we can perform a transition on needs to have its own class that implements this interface. These classes tell the transition system how to act on objects of that type.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.IManagedType.GetManagedType
member.summary: Returns the Type that the instance is managing.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.IManagedType.Copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a deep copy of the object passed in. (In particular this is needed for types that are objects.)

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.IManagedType.GetIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns an object holding the value between the start and end corresponding to the percentage passed in. (Note: the percentage can be less than 0% or greater than 100%.)

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedColor
member.summary: Class that manages transitions for Color properties. For these we need to transition the R, G, B and A sub-properties independently.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedColor.GetManagedType
member.summary: Returns the type we are managing.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedColor.Copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a copy of the color object passed in.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedColor.GetIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates an intermediate value for the colors depending on the percentage passed in.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedDouble
member.summary: Manages transitions for double properties.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedDouble.GetManagedType
member.summary: Returns the type managed by this class.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedDouble.Copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a copy of the double passed in.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedDouble.GetIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the value between start and end for the percentage passed in.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedFloat.GetManagedType
member.summary: Returns the type we're managing.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedFloat.Copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a copy of the float passed in.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedFloat.GetIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the interpolated value for the percentage passed in.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedInt
member.summary: Manages transitions for int properties.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedInt.GetManagedType
member.summary: Returns the type we are managing.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedInt.Copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a copy of the int passed in.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedInt.GetIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the value between the start and end for the percentage passed in.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedString
member.summary: Manages transitions for strings. This doesn't make as much sense as transitions on other types, but I like the way it looks!

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedString.GetManagedType
member.summary: Returns the type we're managing.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedString.Copy(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a copy of the string passed in.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.ManagedTypes.ManagedString.GetIntermediateValue(System.Object,System.Object,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns an "interpolated" string.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.Acceleration
member.summary: Manages transitions under constant acceleration from a standing start.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Acceleration.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Alters the property values to their destination values from a standing start with accelerating intervals.
member.param: The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Acceleration.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Alters the property values to their destination values from a standing start with accelerating intervals.
member.param: The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Acceleration.OnTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in. This uses the formula: s = ut + 1/2at^2 The initial velocity is 0, and the acceleration to get to 1.0 at t=1.0 is 2, so the formula just becomes: s = t^2

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.Bounce
member.summary: This transition bounces the property to a destination value and back to the original value. It is accelerated to the destination and then decelerated back as if being dropped with gravity and bouncing back against gravity.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Bounce.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Bounces the property values to their destination values and back to the original ones. They are accelerated to the destination and then decelerated back as if being dropped with gravity and bouncing back against gravity.
member.param: The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Bounce.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Bounces the property values to their destination values and back to the original ones. They are accelerated to the destination and then decelerated back as if being dropped with gravity and bouncing back against gravity.
member.param: The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.CriticalDamping
member.summary: This transition animates with an exponential decay. This has a damping effect similar to the motion of a needle on an electomagnetically controlled dial.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.CriticalDamping.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Alters the property values with an exponential decay. This has a damping effect similar to the motion of a needle on an electomagnetically controlled dial.
member.param: The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.CriticalDamping.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Alters the property values with an exponential decay. This has a damping effect similar to the motion of a needle on an electomagnetically controlled dial.
member.param: The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.CriticalDamping.OnTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.Deceleration
member.summary: Manages a transition starting from a high speed and decelerating to zero by the end of the transition.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Deceleration.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Alters the property values starting from a high speed and decelerating to zero by the end of the transition.
member.param: The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Deceleration.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Alters the property values starting from a high speed and decelerating to zero by the end of the transition.
member.param: The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Deceleration.OnTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in. This uses the formula: s = ut + 1/2at^2 The initial velocity is 2, and the acceleration to get to 1.0 at t=1.0 is -2, so the formula becomes: s = t(2-t)

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseInEaseOut
member.summary: Manages an ease-in-ease-out transition. This accelerates during the first half of the transition, and then decelerates during the second half.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseInEaseOut.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Alters the property values in an ease-in-ease-out transition. This accelerates during the first half of the transition, and then decelerates during the second half.
member.param: The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseInEaseOut.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Alters the property values in an ease-in-ease-out transition. This accelerates during the first half of the transition, and then decelerates during the second half.
member.param: The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseInEaseOut.OnTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in. This uses the formula: s = ut + 1/2at^2 We accelerate as at the rate needed (a=4) to get to 0.5 at t=0.5, and then decelerate at the same rate to end up at 1.0 at t=1.0.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseWithFunction
member.summary: Allows natural transitions with custom or predefined easing functions. Easing functions are mathematical functions that are used to interpolate values between two endpoints usually with non-linear results. Thanks to Mauro Sampietro for providing the easing functions on https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/827808/Control-Animation-in-Winforms.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseWithFunction.#ctor(FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunction,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Allows natural transitions with custom or predefined easing functions. Easing functions are mathematical functions that are used to interpolate values between two endpoints usually with non-linear results.
member.param: The function to interpolate values with. See "" for prebuilt easing functions. Powererd by Mauro Sampietro (https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/827808/Control-Animation-in-Winforms).
The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseWithFunction.#ctor(FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunction,System.Int32)
member.summary: Allows natural transitions with custom or predefined easing functions. Easing functions are mathematical functions that are used to interpolate values between two endpoints usually with non-linear results.
member.param: The function to interpolate values with. See "" for prebuilt easing functions. Powererd by Mauro Sampietro (https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/827808/Control-Animation-in-Winforms).
The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseWithFunction.OnTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Works out the percentage completed given the time passed in.

member.name: P:FluentTransitions.Methods.EaseWithFunction.EasingFunction
member.summary: Gets the easing function to interpolate values with

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunction
member.summary: Defines the signature of an easing function. Use for prebuilt easing functions matching this signature.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunctions
member.summary: Defines a set of predefined easing functions to choose from when using . Thanks to Mauro Sampietro who wrote about those on CodeProject: https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/827808/Control-Animation-in-Winforms

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunctions.Linear(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Easing equation function for a simple linear tweening, with no easing.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunctions.ExpoEaseOut(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Easing equation function for an exponential (2^currentTime) easing out: decelerating from zero velocity.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunctions.ExpoEaseIn(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Easing equation function for an exponential (2^currentTime) easing in: accelerating from zero velocity.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunctions.ExpoEaseInOut(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Easing equation function for an exponential (2^currentTime) easing in/out: acceleration until halfway, then deceleration.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.EasingFunctions.ExpoEaseOutIn(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Easing equation function for an exponential (2^currentTime) easing out/in: deceleration until halfway, then acceleration.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.summary: Easing equation function for a back (overshooting cubic easing: (s+1)*currentTime^3 - s*currentTime^2) easing out/in: deceleration until halfway, then acceleration.
member.param: The current time to interpolate values with.
The starting value for the interpolation.
The end value for the interpolation.
The total duration of the interpolation.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Methods.Sequence
member.summary:
Allows the creation of user-defined transition methods, specified by a list of individual transition elements.
Each of these defines: End time, End value, Interpolation method
For example, say you want to make a bouncing effect with a decay:
EndTime% EndValue% Interpolation -------- --------- ------------- 50 100 Acceleration 75 50 Deceleration 85 100 Acceleration 91 75 Deceleration 95 100 Acceleration 98 90 Deceleration 100 100 Acceleration
The time values are expressed as a percentage of the overall transition time. This means that you can create a user-defined transition-type and then use it for transitions of different lengths.
The values are percentages of the values between the start and end values of the properties being animated in the transitions. 0% is the start value and 100% is the end value.
The interpolation is one of the values from the InterpolationMethod enum.
So the example above accelerates to the destination (as if under gravity) by t=50%, then bounces back up to half the initial height by t=75%, slowing down (as if against gravity) before falling down again and bouncing to decreasing heights each time.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Methods.Sequence.#ctor
member.summary: Allows the creation of user-defined transition methods, specified by a list of individual transition elements.

member.summary: Allows the creation of user-defined transition methods, specified by a list of individual transition elements.
member.param: The elements to process during the transition
The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.summary: Allows the creation of user-defined transition methods, specified by a list of individual transition elements.
member.param: The elements to process during the transition
The duration in milliseconds until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.IMethod
member.summary: Interface for all transition methods

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.IMethod.OnTimer(System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Called by the Transition framework when its timer ticks to pass in the time (in ms) since the transition started.
You should return (in an out parameter) the percentage movement towards the destination value for the time passed in. Note: this does not need to be a smooth transition from 0% to 100%. You can overshoot with values greater than 100% or undershoot if you need to (for example, to have some form of "elasticity").
The percentage should be returned as (for example) 0.1 for 10%.
You should return (in an out parameter) whether the transition has completed. (This may not be at the same time as the percentage has moved to 100%.)
member.param: The time that has passed
Returns the percentage how far the transition has come
Returns whether the transition has completed or not

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.Transition
member.summary:
Lets you perform animated transitions of properties on arbitrary objects. These will often be transitions of UI properties, for example an animated fade-in of a UI object, or an animated move of a UI object from one position to another.
Each transition can simulataneously change multiple properties, including properties across multiple objects.
Example transition ------------------ a. var transition = new Transition(new Linear(500)); b. transition.add(form1, nameof(Width), 500); c. transition.add(form1, nameof(BackColor), Color.Red); d. transition.run();
Line a: Creates a new transition. You specify the transition method.
Lines b. and c: Set the destination values of the properties you are animating.
Line d: Starts the transition.
Transition methods ------------------ TransitionMethod objects specify how the transition is made. Examples include linear transition, ease-in-ease-out and so on. Different transition methods may need different parameters.

member.name: E:FluentTransitions.Transition.TransitionCompleted

member.summary:
Allows the creation of user-defined transition methods, specified by a list of individual transition elements.
Each of these defines: End time, End value, Interpolation method
For example, say you want to make a bouncing effect with a decay:
EndTime% EndValue% Interpolation -------- --------- ------------- 50 100 Acceleration 75 50 Deceleration 85 100 Acceleration 91 75 Deceleration 95 100 Acceleration 98 90 Deceleration 100 100 Acceleration
The time values are expressed as a percentage of the overall transition time. This means that you can create a user-defined transition-type and then use it for transitions of different lengths.
The values are percentages of the values between the start and end values of the properties being animated in the transitions. 0% is the start value and 100% is the end value.
The interpolation is one of the values from the InterpolationMethod enum.
So the example above accelerates to the destination (as if under gravity) by t=50%, then bounces back up to half the initial height by t=75%, slowing down (as if against gravity) before falling down again and bouncing to decreasing heights each time.

The duration until the properties should have reached their destination values

member.summary: The interpolation method to use when moving between the previous value and the current one.

member.name: T:FluentTransitions.TransitionManager
member.summary: This class is responsible for running transitions. It holds the timer that triggers transition animation.
member.remarks:
This class is a singleton.
We manage the transition timer here so that we can have a single timer across all transitions. If each transition has its own timer, this creates one thread for each transition, and this can lead to too many threads in an application.
This class essentially just manages the timer for the transitions. It calls back into the running transitions, which do the actual work of the transition.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.TransitionManager.#ctor
member.summary: Private constructor (for singleton).

member.summary: Singleton's getInstance method.

member.summary: You register a transition with the manager here. This will start to run the transition as the manager's timer ticks.

member.summary: Checks if any existing transitions are acting on the same properties as the transition passed in. If so, we remove the duplicated properties from the older transitions.

member.summary: Finds any properties in the old-transition that are also in the new one, and removes them from the old one.

member.summary: Called when the timer ticks.

member.name: M:FluentTransitions.Utility.RaiseEvent``1(System.EventHandler{``0},System.Object,``0)
member.summary: Fires the event passed in in a thread-safe way.
member.remarks: This method loops through the targets of the event and invokes each in turn. If the target supports ISychronizeInvoke (such as forms or controls) and is set to run on a different thread, then we call BeginInvoke to marshal the event to the target thread. If the target does not support this interface (such as most non-form classes) or we are on the same thread as the target, then the event is fired on the same thread as this is called from.
